cards.name: Snake Oil Salesman
cards.originalText:
{T}: Create a colorless artifact token named Snake Oil.
{3}{U}{U}, {T}: Exchange control of two target nonland permanents for as long as you control Snake Oil Salesman.

rulings.text: Control is only exchanged if both targets are still legal as the ability resolves.
If you exchange the Salesman for something, that exchange will remain active as long as you would control the Salesman if not for the exchange. Any other exchanges will end immediately.

If Snake Oil Salesman leaves the battlefield or leaves your control through some other effect, the control-changing effects immediately end and control of the permanents returns to the previous player. If one of the permanents no longer exists, the other is still returned.
If any creatures are involved in the exchange, they will become summoning sick both when the effect begins and when it ends.

cards.name: Pactbound Simians
cards.originalText:
Flying
At the beginning of your upkeep, choose one that hasn't been chosen —
• Target opponent sacrifices a creature.
• Target opponent discards a card.
• Target opponent sacrifices a land.
• Sacrifice Pactbound Simians.

rulings.text: You choose the mode as the triggered ability goes on the stack. You can choose a mode that requires targets only if there are legal targets available.
If the ability is countered (either for having its target become illegal or because a spell or ability counters it), the mode chosen for that instance of the ability still counts as being chosen.

The phrase "that hasn't been chosen" refers only to that specific Pactbound Simians. If you control one and cast another one, you can choose any mode for the second one the first time its ability triggers.

It doesn't matter who has chosen any particular mode. For example, say you control Pactbound Simians and have chosen the first two modes. If an opponent gains control of Pactbound Simians, that player can choose only the third or fourth mode.

In some very unusual situations, you may not be able to choose a mode, either because all modes have previously been chosen or the only remaining modes require targets and there are no legal targets available. In this case, the ability is simply removed from the stack with no effect.
Yes, if the fourth mode is the only one remaining, you must choose it. You read the whole contract, right?

cards.originalText: Until end of turn, target creature gets +6/+6 and gains trample, and all creatures able to block it this turn do so.

rulings.text: If, during the declare blockers step, a creature the defending player controls is tapped (or untapped, if the targeted creature has dreamwalk) or is affected by a spell or ability that says it can't block, then it doesn't block. If there's a cost associated with having it block, its controller isn't forced to pay that cost. If he or she doesn't, the creature doesn't have to block.

If a creature can't legally block the targeted creature but could block another attacking creature, it may do so. Likewise, if a creature the defending player controls can't block the targeted creature unless its controller pays a cost, its controller may decline to pay that cost and block a different attacking creature.

rulings.text: The ability that triggers when Colossus of Railroads dies doesn't target any of the creatures. You can choose to put counters on a creature with protection from artifacts, for example.
